sn20.7:1.2: The Dasārahas were probably the people known in Sanskrit as the Daśārṇa of the western Vindhya mountains. | The mudiṅga is a double-headed drum known today as mridangam, which is still widely used in southern India. It is named for the paste (“mud”, today called the karanai) applied to one of the heads that gives it its distinctive snare-like tone (chapu). The skin is attached with a wooden rim tightened with leather straps. | Āṇaka is another name for what is said to be a large military drum, which might be named after āṇi in the sense of “tuning peg”, a feature of the modern mardala. However, in this case, the context requires that the āṇi be a plug for patching the shell, after which the drum was named “Plugger”.
sn20.7:1.4: The pokkhara is the “drumskin”. The phalaka is the “wooden shell”, a single hollowed-out log from which the mridangam is constructed.
